reviews.review_msg: Love this guy. Lectures can be a touch boring but his sense of humour makes up for it. He told us not to eat during the exam because we would choke from anxiety and he wouldn't know how to save us lmao. Gives out exam Qs beforehand and they are easy. Start the paper early. He can go off on tangents for sure, but it's not really a bad thing.

Really nice professor. He doesn't want his students to be stressed out about the exams or the course in general. He offers all possible help, so it is up to you whether you take advantage of it! Lectures are grounded in his knowledge, and he provides plenty of examples to help you understand the context. More then enough for success! Recommended!

Super easy GPA booster. Didn't go to a single lecture and still passed with an A. He will tell you exactly which questions will be on midterm and final which are super easy short answer questions. Essay is worth a lot so get started on it early and you will be fine. Chill class.

Tests are easy if you study. He gives you a study guide and those questions are literally what you get tested on. If you have a good TA I'm sure the class would have been good or at least DECENT. Not in my case... Never responded to emails. No one ever even showed up to lectures.

I dont think he's “awful” but he's definitely not great either. Lectures were imposible to understand because of his accent, it got so bad that by the third week it was almost an empty lecture hall. There was no tutorial so it made it harder to actually learn something. Tests were very easy but the term paper worth 35% had no clear grading criteria

grading criteria for exams and term paper were very unclear. lectures were 3hrs of rambling nonsense (has a thick accent so very hard to understand), would skip slides and go off on tangents frequently. the material was not focused on Canada's justice system which the course was supposed to be about, overall i learned everything from the textbook

Lectures were very boring, often 2 straight hours of rambling and going off topic into very specific examples that weren't relevant. I found it incredibly difficult to focus in lectures, which I have never struggled with before. Out of the 300 people in the course, a whopping 20 actually showed up to lectures. The textbook was well written though.

There were 2 in-class assignments, for which he provided the prompts beforehand. Other than that, I rarely attended class due to his heavy accent and tendency to get sidetracked. He posts a comprehensive list of questions for both tests. Overall, the course is manageable without attending lectures as long as you review the slides and readings.

He's a really nice guy, however it was quite difficult to do even remotely well on the tests because of his unclear expectations (ie the midterm and final  averages were in the 60's range). He was generous with the marking of the paper though, and he does provide the questions for tests beforehand which is nice.

HOW IS HE STILL HIRED BY SFU

Starts side tracking wayyy tooo much during lectures. The only good thing I could say about his class is that all of his exam questions are given earlier from a list of questions beforehand.

He has a strong Russian accent, so beware. However, his exams are quite easy as he provides a list of questions which he pulls exam questions out of. His instructions aren't clear for assignments. His papers  are long so give yourself enough time to write it, proofread it etc.

He is a very kind prof and seems to know his content but I think he just has trouble conveying it sometimes and often skips a lot of the slides he posts while lecturing. The course is graded only by a few things and his accent is strong but he tries to work around it. He does tell you exactly what will be on the exams though which is great.

-Is sweet guy 
-He has a really thick accent
-He provides a link on Canvas to a list of questions that relate to the lecture find the answers to those questions and read the textbook don't have to attend the lectures
-The questions compiled into a list of questions that he uses for the mid-term and finals 
-He only does one big paper for the course

A kind but rambling prof. Rarely gets through all the slides because he goes off topic, so get ready to review by yourself. Do the practice Qs, the exam Qs are pulled from them. Entertaining anecdotes and a good sense of humour. Paper guidelines are vague, but he grades fairly. If you're hard of hearing or can't understand a Russian accent, beware.

Not a bad professor, but is hard to understand because of the accent. Gives you a list of questions from the textbook & selects a few to be on the midterm + final. Read the textbook, study the questions provided & there should be no reason you can't do well. Term paper is minimum 10 pages which is reasonable and should be expected in Crim.

I don't get all the hate, his anecdotes are amusing and his accent is 50x better than some of the professors I've had here. Content and feature documentaries are fairly interesting, and the midterm was easy. Only studied the day before it and did fairly well, and the final was online as well. Start the 10pg term paper early and show up to tutorials

Honestly it's been like 11 weeks since the semester started, I have no clue if he is good and only cause I do not understand single thing that he says. Also his big paper of the class kind of has inconsistent criteria, the doc given to us for it says 10-12 pages but the syllabus that he "updated" says 8-10 so I have no clue what is real or not:(

Easy material. Very hard to follow him. He has an accent and speaks super quietly. He goes of topic all the time and makes things more confusing. You have to teach yourself everything. He's office hours are more confusing and he is our TA. Aka we sit for 4hrs every Monday listening to him just talk. No grades posted yet. Wish i did not take

His accent is very hard to understand, but all his exam questions come from the Textbook learning objectives. He provides a list of all the exam questions beforehand, so you will have plenty of time to memorize the questions. From that list, he will choose about 10-11 questions. It's extremely easy to do well in this class. Just read the textbook.

First year crim major, he's a cool guy but his accent makes it extremely difficult to understand. He starts talking about random things and it's easy to get lost. He gives out practice questions that are based on lectures, videos and textbooks so as long as you do them and memorize it the midterm is really easy.

Great guy! Hard to understand and often goes off topic, but his lessons are straight forward and he provides a question bank before the exam and he selects of a number of those and tests you on it. Long paper but broad topics. Not really necessary to go to class, just do the readings/watch the videos provided as they'll set you up for the exams.
The professor talks about the Russian legal system in a Canadian legal system course. Such a joke. His accent is indecipherable and talks far too quietly.
Probably the worst prof SFU has to offer. You cannot understand a word he says. Syllabus is out-of-date. He does not respond to emails and without a TA you're basically doomed.

His accent is heavy and sounds like he's mumbling half the time. Provided questions that would be on the exams but those questions couldn't be answered with textbook alone but due his accent, I couldn't pick up any info from lecture making it impossible to answer the questions he provided. I switched to a diff prof
Heavy accent, bad slides, quiet and super hard to follow even if you are listening to him like super hard

He was very difficult to understand in lecture (strong accent, would pace around, spoke quietly), and he jumped around topics in the lecture, making it hard to follow. Lectures aren't mandatory - just read the chapter and keep up on the textbook questions because he chooses from a question bank given beforehand for exams). Long paper, start early.

Nice (but yappy) professor, test heavy but pretty easy.

His lectures are 90% him talking about random things, he doesn't finish his thoughts and can be hard to understand. His testing is all based on the practice question he supplies. Attendance is not necessary, but reading the textbook and watching the videos/extra sources he posts are.
W prof, the best CRIM prof SFU has to offer. Understanding, caring and his Russian accent makes him even cooler. Would 100%% take his class again. Recommend him at all costs

Super easy! questions given weekly (answer using the textbook). He chooses 6 short answers out of these, 10 mc, 5 t/f on mt + final. Also gives answers to t/f + mc, so easy to memorize. Never attended a lec. Paper kinda hard (my topic = poverty + crime rates), overall minimum effort class + highly recommend.

OH MY GOD! I took this class as an elective but I got an A in this class. I always got 20% above the average. The teacher is so caring and kind. He is always there to accommodate you whenever you need. The exams were easy as hell. Straight memorizing. Make sure you attempt the practice exams, they were extremely helpful! I'm very serious! Must take

Hard to understand because of his accent, but lectures were pretty much copy & paste from the textbook. Do the weekly questions he posts as these will literally be your exams (any of them are fair game) & are easy enough to memorize. Exams are 30% each, Paper 30% (8-14 pages, but broad enough topic that it wasn't hard) & Tutorials 10%. Easy enough.

Dry and hard to understand, It was two exams and a research paper, the paper is easy and broad, but time consuming. The exams are easy because he gives you the list of questions that will be on the exams so all you have to do is memorize them. If you have to take this class and want a decent grade without going to a single lecture, do it with him.
cant understand a word he says. challenging professor, not kind. very lazy slides, assignments too challenging for what it is

It can be hard to understand him sometimes, but he's unintentionally funny. His lectures are posted online and summarize the textbook well. He basically posts the entire midterm and end-of-term online, and it's just memorization to prepare for them. I was late for the end-of-term test with 25 minutes left, but he let me take it.

He is so cute. Straight-up grandpa vibes. It's a little hard to understand him because he has a strong accent, but tests are straightforward and he sends a question bank beforehand with what he's gonna put on the exam. He's always helpful when you ask him questions.

Nikolay Shchitov is extremely disorganized, and the grading criteria are very unclear, when asked in person about the criteria he gives each student a different answer when we asked the same questions. He does not communicate with the TAs, so they don't know what to do either.

Proffesor Shchitov is an amazing lecturer, who cares for his students and wants them to succeed. He gives out the midterm/final questions out beforehand. All you need to do is memorize them since they're all fair game. Also make sure to answer the questions he posts for lectures, it'll help you for your exams.

Pretty good prof, midterm and final consisted of 11 short answer questions, but he gives out all the questions beforehand, you just have to memorize them. No point in showing up for lectures, just make sure to complete the questions each week. Paper was pretty long (10-17 pages), but pretty manageable.

*Crim314 Dr. Shchitov is a fair prof, who has the standard midterm, final, paper, & participation. The slides are thorough that go over the exam questions. However, to be successful in this class, you must keep up with the weekly discussion questions as they are necessary for both participation and exams. Highly recommend Dr. Shchitov.

*Crim314
Dr Shchitov gets a bit off-topic during lectures it's fun but his slides are barebones/vague at times so you really need to read.
I like the variety in reading/videos but the fact they're low resolution scans are a bit annoying.
We get test questions ahead of time, & marks are relatively generous.
It's a bit hard to really participate.

The lectures often took a turn to another subject and his accent made the content hard to follow. He is very nice to talk to, but the in-person exams stressed me out and I often had to teach myself about the subject. The paper criteria was very confusing and he took a long time to release the exam dates.

Participation in tutorials is worth a lot and marks on tests/papers depend on how lenient your TA is. I liked how he basically gave you all of the questions on the exam; its just a matter of memorization. His accent can be hard to understand but honestly just answering the question list can get you an A-B. Beware of the 10-page paper, start early!!

Took his Crim 131 class back in Spring 2020. His exams are quite easy if you study his lecture slides. Didn't really use the textbook at all for it. Paper is easy to do, just follow his guidelines for it and ask questions to your TA or him if necessary. All in all a solid and kind prof. Would recommend.

If you take a class by Shchitov, prepare to read the text book and teach yourself. When he teaches, he goes off topic. That accent of his makes it difficult to understand him too. As for the papers, he doesnt lay out criteria for them. Exams wise, he takes from the review questions of the textbook and his own review questions for lecture slides.

He goes off topic quite often that you will find yourself not being able to follow his words every lecture time. So I did not find his lecture nor interesting or helpful. He seems a hard marker with no specific criteria especially for papers.

His lectures are kind of pointless to attend since he posts everything, and it can be hard to understand him at times. Do the readings, go to tutorials and participate, follow the criteria for all assignments and ask questions, and you will be fine.
Just read the textbook. The exam questions are all picked from a list he gives beforehand, so it's super easy to do well.

I actually quite enjoyed this course, probably the first class that I've ever read the textbook front to back, definitely reflects what's on the midterm and final. Tends to go off topic during lecture but likes to discuss current day issues, in relation to policing ofc, not completely off topic

Nikolay was fine but I would not take him again. He goes off topic all the time so you don't really know what to pay attention too. Going to lecture was definitely not important, it was mostly just textbook readings and paper. He takes questions from the first chapter's learning goals so study those and you'll ace the tests.

This class was very enjoyable, he was very clear of what would be on the exams. He lets you pick a topic for the term paper with no guidelines of what he wants it to be on. His accent can be hard to understand but I do recommend this class.

I loved Professor Shchitov. I took his class Spring 2020 so everything was moved online halfway through, and he was really understanding. There was 1 paper due at the very end that we got in the first week, so we had the whole semester to do it. He also gives a complete question list for the midterm&final, so evrything is laid out 4 you. Great guy.
Seems to want his students to succeed. Study from the list of questions he gives for exams, it is extremely helpful that he gives it out.

a bit hard to understand at times, has interesting stories, gives out a list of questions prior to exam which is pretty fair, if you go over the list you'll do fine. seems like a nice guy who wants to see you do well!

Really interesting guy. This class is not easy, and the textbook is hard to read at times, so you have to read ahead of lecture. Don't try and write everything down from the slides, instead focus on the extra material he talks about that isn't in his lecture material. Has pretty crazy stories about friends back in Russia.

Lectures were long and often went completely off-topic. Participation was 20% of the grade yet rarely made time for discussion and never recorded who did talk. Gave very vague instructions for the paper. Exams are short answer from a HUGE list of questions he gives out. Doesn't respond to emails. No textbook- lots of articles. Would not recommend.

Dr.S is awesome. Sometimes it might be hard to understand what he's saying, but need not worry! This class has 3 tests and a paper. For all 3 tests he posts a big list of study questions the week before the testand all the questions that will appear on the tests come from that list. He really wants his students to do well!
